title: `std::fs::create_dir_all`: unexpected behavior with `..`

labels.name: T-libs
labels.description: Relevant to the library team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: A-io
labels.description: Area: std::io, std::fs, std::net and std::path

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
fn main() {
  assert!(!std::path::Path::new("/tmp/foobar").exists());
  std::fs::create_dir_all("/tmp/foobar/..").unwrap();
  assert!(!std::path::Path::new("/tmp/foobar").exists());
}
```

I expected to see this happen:
- the second assertion should not fire

Instead, this happened:
- the second assertion did fire

I don't see this behavior documented anywhere and to me it is vastly unexpected: it is unambiguous that `/tmp/foobar/..` refers to `/tmp/` from what I can tell, and so that's what I expect to be created (if it does not exist yet). The documentation mentions that `create_dir_all` is implemented via `mkdir`, but its manpage doesn't hint at this behavior either. Interestingly, Python seems to have [a note](https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.makedirs) about this peculiarity (haven't looked at either implementation).
